conclusion: To find the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the \( \nu \)-shaped current-carrying wire, we can proceed step by step.
The wire is bent into a \( \nu \)-shape, forming an angle of \( 60^\circ \) between the two equal sides.
Each side of the \( \nu \)-shape has length \( l \), so the total length of the wire is \( 2l \).
The wire is placed in a uniform magnetic field \( B \) that is perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
A current \( I \) flows through the wire.
The force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by \( \mathbf{F} = I \mathbf{L} \times \mathbf{B} \).

premise: Since the magnetic field \( B \) is perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
conclusion: The direction of the force on each segment will be perpendicular to both the current and the magnetic field.

premise: For each segment of length \( l \), the force is \( F = I l B \).
conclusion: The force on each segment is \( F = I l B \).

premise: The forces on the two segments form an angle of \( 60^\circ \) between them.
conclusion: To find the resultant force, we need to resolve these forces into components and add them vectorially.

premise: Each force \( F \) can be resolved into components along the x and y axes.
conclusion: The components will be \( F_x = F \cos(30^\circ) = I l B \cos(30^\circ) \) and \( F_y = F \sin(30^\circ) = I l B \sin(30^\circ) \).

premise: The resultant force can be found by adding the vector components of the forces from both segments.
conclusion: The magnitude of the resultant force is \( F_{\text{resultant}} = \sqrt{(2 I l B \cos(30^\circ))^2 + 0} = 2 I l B \cos(30^\circ) \).

premise: The magnitude of the resultant force is \( 2 I l B \cos(30^\circ) \).
conclusion: The magnitude of the resultant force is \( 2 I l B \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) = I l B \sqrt{3} \).

premise: The magnitude of the resultant force is \( I l B \sqrt{3} \).
conclusion: Therefore, the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the \( \nu \)-shaped current-carrying wire is \( I l B \sqrt{3} \).
